rev.comment: /* Cultural and religious aspects */ Remove commentary on random websites.
/* Cultural and religious aspects */ grammar, unify paragraph
/* Islam */ Quote was incomplete, and Musa Mohammed Omer does seem to be from Ethiopia.
Use link direct to reuters.com -- article apparently had been retitled... "circumcision rites gone wrong" does raise an eyebrow indeed

map image removed with no scientific data to back its claims
removal of factual claims with no references provided.

/* Cultural and religious aspects */ No reason for this quote to have been under Judaism.
/* Cultural and religious aspects */ When parts of an article contradict each other, best to present the sources neutrally. Also the USSD seems better here since it's not specific to Judaism
/* Cultural and religious aspects */ rv the rv. Question: is it the [[WP:NPOV]] to assert that anyone is doing anything that is "contrary to their religion"
Citation maintenance. Added: location. Formatted: publisher, doi. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself! Please [[User:DOI_bot/bugs|report any bugs]].

/* In Literature and Films */ Added link
/* Judaism */ cites two sources which do not say this
Date maintenance tags and general fixes
Just realized that the lead sentence contradicted the view of Shaykh Faraz Rabbani, cited here, that clitoral hood trimming is not FGM. [[WP:NPOV]] calls on us to state one definition.
/* Judaism */ two different things. one is the cutting off of the foreskin, the other, a religious ceremony involving the former -- in this sentence, we refer to the former.
/* Cultural and religious aspects */ remove phrase contradicted by sourced material elsewhere in the article
This article is biased. It gives a distinctly negative, western perspective of FGM. In reality the removal of the clitoral hood causes no more damage than the removal of the male foreskin.

/* Type III: Infibulation with excision */ the procedure is critized to be done in the favor of men ,and that repeated intercourse may cause more damage to the wound.

Added another long term medical effect that is commonly associated with female genital cutting
rv [[WP:NPOV|non-NPOV]] ("often overlooked," "important to understand," etc.), also FGM is always on females by definition. Please also be careful also about flagging edits as [[WP:MINOR|minor]].
This page called for more attention to the introduction on Female Genital Cutting so I have editted it to draw some more interest to the topic and changed some of the wording to make it easy to read.
